InfoTravel.title: Traveling to Congo
InfoTravel.subtitle: Everything you need to know to prepare your trip to Kinshasa and Kongo Central with peace of mind.
InfoTravel.s1Text: Entering the DRC requires a visa. The process is straightforward if you're well prepared.
InfoTravel.s1Item1: e-Visa available via evisa.gouv.cd — approximately $100 for a single entry
InfoTravel.s1Item2: Additional arrival fee of approximately $90 payable at the airport
InfoTravel.s1Item3: Passport must be valid for at least 6 months beyond your entry date
InfoTravel.s1Item4: Yellow fever vaccination certificate is mandatory
InfoTravel.s2Text: Congo has a tropical climate with two main seasons. Choosing the right time makes all the difference.
InfoTravel.s2Item1: Dry season from June to September — ideal for traveling
InfoTravel.s2Item2: Rainy season from October to May — frequent afternoon showers
InfoTravel.s2Item4: Roads are in worse condition during the rainy season
InfoTravel.s3Text: A few health precautions are essential for a worry-free stay.
InfoTravel.s3Item1: Yellow fever: mandatory vaccination (yellow card required)
InfoTravel.s3Item4: Travel insurance with repatriation coverage is essential
InfoTravel.s4Text: Travel light and smart — here are the essentials for Congo.
InfoTravel.s4Item1: Light, breathable cotton or linen clothing
InfoTravel.s4Item2: A compact raincoat or umbrella for sudden showers
InfoTravel.s4Item3: DEET-based mosquito repellent and European power adapter (Type C/E)
InfoTravel.s4Item4: Copies of important documents (passport, visa, insurance)
InfoTravel.s5Text: Stay connected easily with local mobile operators.
InfoTravel.s5Item1: Vodacom, Airtel, or Orange SIM cards available at the airport ($2-10)
InfoTravel.s5Item2: 4G network available in Kinshasa and major cities
InfoTravel.s5Item3: eSIM option available for compatible smartphones
InfoTravel.s6Text: Kinshasa and Kongo Central are safe destinations for well-informed visitors.
InfoTravel.s6Item1: Kinshasa is safe for tourists — Gombe is the most secure neighborhood
InfoTravel.s6Item2: Avoid photographing government and military buildings
InfoTravel.s6Item3: Use pre-arranged transport rather than street taxis
InfoTravel.s6Item4: Keep valuables discreet and stay alert in crowded areas
InfoTravel.tip: KinXplore assists you with all your visa and entry formalities. Our team handles everything so you can travel with peace of mind.

InfoTransport.title: Getting around
InfoTransport.subtitle: A practical guide to transportation in Kinshasa and to Kongo Central for confident travel.
InfoTransport.s1Text: Several options exist for moving around the capital, but some are better suited for visitors.
InfoTransport.s1Item1: The Yango app is recommended — rides from $1.50 to $15 depending on distance
InfoTransport.s1Item2: Private driver for the day: $80-120 — the best option for exploring
InfoTransport.s1Item3: Avoid shared taxis if you don't know the city
InfoTransport.s2Text: Kongo Central is accessible from Kinshasa by road or train.
InfoTransport.s2Item1: National Road 1: approximately 350 km to Matadi (5-7 hours drive)
InfoTransport.s2Item2: Kinshasa-Matadi train restored in September 2025 — a scenic alternative
InfoTransport.s2Item3: An experienced driver is essential for this journey
InfoTransport.s3Text: Kinshasa is a megacity of 17 million people. Traffic can be intense.
InfoTransport.s3Item1: Rush hours: 6:30-9 AM and 4-7 PM — avoid if possible
InfoTransport.s3Item2: Crossing the city can take 1 to 2 hours depending on traffic
InfoTransport.s3Item3: Always plan generous buffers in your schedule
InfoTransport.s4Text: Road conditions vary considerably depending on the routes.
InfoTransport.s4Item1: The N1 is paved but in variable condition — watch for potholes
InfoTransport.s4Item2: Secondary roads are often unpaved — a 4x4 is recommended
InfoTransport.s4Item3: Roadblocks (checkpoints) are common — a local driver knows how to handle them
InfoTransport.s5Text: For long distances, local airlines serve the main cities.
InfoTransport.s5Item1: Air Congo and flyCAA for long-distance connections
InfoTransport.s5Item2: No flight needed for Kongo Central from Kinshasa
InfoTransport.s5Item3: Book flights in advance — availability can be limited
InfoTransport.s6Text: In Kinshasa, having a private driver isn't a luxury — it's a practical necessity.
InfoTransport.s6Item1: Traffic is chaotic and there's no reliable road signage
InfoTransport.s6Item2: A local driver knows how to navigate checkpoints and roadblocks
InfoTransport.s6Item3: In case of a breakdown, your driver handles everything on the spot
InfoTransport.s6Item4: KinXplore offers a private driver service for all your transportation needs
InfoTransport.tip: KinXplore offers a private driver transport service for all your trips in Kinshasa and to Kongo Central. Safety, punctuality, and comfort guaranteed.

InfoCurrency.title: Currency in Congo
InfoCurrency.subtitle: Everything you need to know about money, payments, and budgeting for your stay in the DRC.
InfoCurrency.s1Text: The official currency of the DRC is the Congolese Franc, but the US dollar reigns supreme.
InfoCurrency.s1Item1: Indicative rate: approximately 2,125 CDF to 1 USD
InfoCurrency.s1Item2: Banknotes in circulation: from 50 FC to 20,000 FC
InfoCurrency.s1Item3: The economy is heavily dollarized — USD is used everywhere
InfoCurrency.s2Text: The dollar is the reference currency in Kinshasa. A few important rules to know.
InfoCurrency.s2Item1: Bills must be in good condition and dated after 2013 — older bills are refused
InfoCurrency.s2Item2: $100 bills get the best exchange rate
InfoCurrency.s2Item3: Also bring small denominations ($1, $5, $10) for everyday expenses
InfoCurrency.s3Text: Several options are available for exchange, but the need is limited since dollars are widely accepted.
InfoCurrency.s3Item1: Banks (Rawbank, Equity BCDC) — official rates, longer process
InfoCurrency.s3Item2: Street money changers — often better rates, always negotiate
InfoCurrency.s3Item3: Hotels — convenient but less favorable rates
InfoCurrency.s4Text: ATMs exist but aren't always reliable. Plan to bring cash.
InfoCurrency.s4Item1: Rawbank has the most extensive ATM network
InfoCurrency.s4Item2: ATMs can be out of service — don't rely on them exclusively
InfoCurrency.s4Item3: Visa and Mastercard sometimes accepted, but bring cash as your primary source
InfoCurrency.s5Text: Mobile payment is booming in Congo and very practical for daily use.
InfoCurrency.s5Item2: Airtel Money and Orange Money also available
InfoCurrency.s5Item3: Set up your account with a local SIM card at the airport
InfoCurrency.s6Text: Kinshasa is one of Africa's most expensive cities for visitors. Here are some benchmarks.
InfoCurrency.s6Item2: Driver: $5-10 per day as a tip
InfoCurrency.s6Item4: Accommodation: from $40 (guesthouse) to $400 (luxury hotel) per night
InfoCurrency.tip: Kinshasa is one of Africa's most expensive cities for visitors. Plan your budget accordingly and bring enough clean US dollar bills.
